raw_text:
Moving mobile improves golf swing
 
 A mobile phone that recognises and responds to movements has been launched in Japan.
 
 The motion-sensitive phone - officially titled the V603SH - was developed by Sharp and launched by Vodafone's Japanese division. Devised mainly for mobile gaming, users can also access other phone functions using a pre-set pattern of arm movements. The phone will allow golf fans to improve their swing via a golfing game.
 
 Those who prefer shoot-'em-ups will be able to use the phone like a gun to shoot the zombies in the mobile version of Sega's House of the Dead. The phone comes with a tiny motion-control sensor, a computer chip that responds to movement.
 
 Other features include a display screen that allows users to watch TV and can rotate 180 degrees. It also doubles up as an electronic musical instrument. Users have to select a sound from a menu that includes clapping, tambourine and maracas and shake their phone to create a beat. It is being recommended for the karaoke market. The phone will initially be available in Japan only and is due to go on sale in mid-February. The new gadget could make for interesting people-watching among Japanese commuters, who are able to access their mobiles on the subway. Fishing afficiandos in South Korea are already using a phone that allows them to simulate the movement of a rod. The PH-S6500 phone, dubbed a sports-leisure gadget, was developed by Korean phone giant Pantech and can also be used by runners to measure calorie consumption and distance run.
llama3.2:1b: A mobile phone with motion-sensitive capabilities, V603SH, has been launched in Japan by Sharp for use as an electronic musical instrument.
It is designed for golf enthusiasts who want to improve their swing through a golfing game.
The phone also features other gaming elements such as shoot-'em-ups and a karaoke mode that allows users to create music using the phone's motion-control sensor.
llama3.2:3b: A mobile phone with a motion-sensitive sensor has been launched in Japan for gaming and other uses, including improving golf swings via a golfing game.
It features a tiny sensor, display screen that rotates 180 degrees, and can be used as an electronic musical instrument.

The phone is recommended for the karaoke market and will initially be available only in Japan, with similar technology already being used in South Korea for fishing simulators and runners to track calorie consumption and distance run.
gemma2:2b: A new motion-sensitive mobile phone called V603SH from Sharp has been launched in Japan.

This phone uses arm movements to control functions like playing games (e.g., House of the Dead), watching TV, and even creating music,  making it a potential tool for both gaming and everyday activities.
It is currently available only in Japan and will be released mid-February.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A mobile phone designed to improve golfers' swings has been released in Japan.
It uses motion-sensitive technology that responds to arm movements using pre-set patterns.
Golf fans can use the phone's camera-like display screen, rotation control, and built-in music player to practice their strokes.
The new gadget is expected to make for interesting commuter views among Japanese commuters who use their mobiles on trains, subway systems, or in parks.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A motion-sensitive mobile phone capable of improving golf swing and playing games has been launched in Japan.
Users can access various functions using pre-set patterns of arm movements.
The device features a tiny motion-control sensor, computer chip, display screen for watching TV, rotating 180 degrees, and electronic musical instrument capabilities.
It will initially be available only in Japan and is set to go on sale mid-February.
qwen2.5:3b: A motion-sensitive smartphone called V603SH, developed by Sharp and launched by Vodafone's Japanese division, allows users to play golf games improving their swing.
It features a sensor that responds to movement for phone functions including gaming and controlling TV.
Other uses include playing karaoke or simulating fishing rod movements.
Initially available only in Japan, it could also attract commuters watching others use their phones on subways.
opencoder:1.5b: The mobile phone that recognises and responds to movements has been launched in Japan for golf swing improvements.

Devised mainly for mobile gaming, users can also access other phone functions using a pre-set pattern of arm movements.
The phone will allow golf fans to improve their swing via a golfing game.
Those who prefer shoot-'em-ups will be able to use the phone like a gun to shoot the zombies in the mobile version of Sega's House of the Dead.
Other features include a display screen that allows users to watch TV and can rotate 180 degrees.
It also doubles up as an electronic musical instrument.
Users have to select a sound from a menu that includes clapping, tambourine and maracas and shake their phone to create a beat.
The phone will initially be available in Japan only and is due to go on sale in mid-February.
Other gadgets include fishing afficiandos in South Korea which are already using a phone that allows them to simulate the movement of a rod.
Korean phone giant Pantech developed the PH-S6500 phone, dubbed a sports-leisure gadget.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: A mobile phone that recognizes and responds to movements has been launched in Japan, known as the V603SH (officially described as the V603SH).
It was developed by Sharp and part of Vodafone's Japanese division.
The device allows golf fans to improve their swing through a golfing game.
Users can also use it like a gun for a zombie shooter mobile version of Sega's House of the Dead, with controls from a menu featuring clapping, tambourine sounds, and maracas.
It doubles as an electronic musical instrument and is intended for karaoke.

Other features include a display for watching TV, rotating 180 degrees, a small motion-control sensor, and sound features (clapping, tambourine, maracas) with the ability to shake the phone to create beats.
This device is being recommended for the karaoke market.
The V603SH, called a sports-leisure gadget, was developed by Korean phone giant Pantech and can be used by runners to measure distance run.
tinyllama:1.1b: Sharp's mobile phone is now available in Japan, boasting motion-sensitive capabilities that allow users to practice swing improvement while enjoying various video games or playing House of the Dead shooter.

In addition to a display screen that can rotate 180 degrees and an electronic musical instrument, the V603SH features a mobile gaming platform, allowing users to access other phone functions like TV viewing or electronic musical instruments.
The device is recommended for people who want to learn how to improve their swing while simultaneously indulging in their favorite video games.
While initially designed for Japan's commuters, the new gadget could potentially make for interesting people-watching among subway users in Seoul.
Furthermore, South Korean fishing aficionados have already used a phone that allows them to simulate the movements of fishing rods.
The PH-S6500 is known as a sports-leisure gadget and can also be used by runners to track calorie consumption and distance while running.
tinydolphin:1.1b: A new gaming-focused mobile device has been launched in Japan, specifically for gamers who enjoy playing House of the Dead on their mobile devices.
This new device from Sharp is known as the V603SH and it comes with a miniature motion-sensing sensor that can recognize and respond to user movements.
The phone will not only help gamers improve their gaming skills but also provide other users with an electronic musical instrument, a TV screen, and even the ability to play karaoke.
This new device from Sharp aims to make sports enthusiasts and leisurely gaming fanatics feel more engaged while they are exercising or watching their favorite shows on the phone's display.
phi:2.7b: A new Japanese mobile phone with motion sensing technology has been launched for gaming and other functions like golfing, shooting zombies, watching TV, playing musical instruments, karaoke and running.
The V603SH is pre-set with certain movements that can be used to access different features on the phone.
It will initially be available only in Japan but may become popular among people who use it for interesting observation.
There are other phones like PH-S6508 in South Korea that allow users to simulate fishing or measure calorie consumption and distance run using motion sensing technology.
orca-mini:3b: A mobile phone that recognizes and responds to movements has been launched in Japan as a motion-sensitive phone.
It is designed mainly for mobile gaming and allows golf fans to improve their swing via a golfing game.
Other features include a display screen that allows users to watch TV and can rotate 180 degrees, and it also doubles up as an electronic musical instrument.
Users have to select a sound from a menu that includes clapping, tambourine, and maracas and shake their phone to create a beat.
It is being recommended for the karaoke market.
The phone will initially be available in Japan only and is due to go on sale in mid-February.
hermes3:3b: Mobile phone recognizes movements for improved golf swing (for golf game) (Japan launch)
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A motion-sensitive mobile phone developed by Sharp and launched in Japan is designed for both mobile gaming and accessing other phone functions using pre-set arm movements.
Golf fans can use the phone to improve their swing through a golfing game, while shoot-'em-up fans can use it like a gun to take down zombies in Sega's House of the Dead.
The phone also features a 180-degree rotating display screen and can be used as an electronic musical instrument for karaoke purposes.
It is initially available in Japan and set to launch in South Korea soon, attracting attention from commuters and fitness enthusiasts alike.
stablelm2:1.6b: A motion-sensitive phone called VodafoneSH by Sharp has been launched in Japan for mobile gaming and golf swing improvement through a game.
The device allows users to access various functions via arm movements, with shoot-'em-up and karaoke functionalities also available.
Initially available only in Japan, the new gadget could lead to interesting people-watching among commuters on subways.
granite3.1-dense:2b: A Japanese mobile phone, the V603SH (Vodafone Japan's Sharp-developed device), has debuted, featuring a motion-sensitive sensor for gaming and other functions.

This phone, set for mid-February release in Japan, offers users the ability to play mobile games like Sega's House of the Dead as a gun or engage in golfing simulations through an app to improve their swings.
It also includes a 180-degree rotatable display for TV viewing and serves as a musical instrument with various sound options that users can create by shaking the device.
The phone is marketed towards commuters who might use it on trains, providing entertainment during travel.

In South Korea, a similar sports-leisure phone, PH-S6500 (developed by Pantech), caters to anglers and runners, allowing them to measure calorie burn and distance covered while running or simulate fishing rod movements.
chatgpt-4o-latest: A motion-sensitive mobile phone, the V603SH, developed by Sharp and launched by Vodafone Japan, recognizes and responds to movements.
Primarily designed for gaming, it allows users to control functions through arm movements.
Golfers can improve their swing with a golfing game, while others can play a shooting game by mimicking a gun.
The phone features a motion-control sensor, a rotatable display for watching TV, and can function as a musical instrument for karaoke enthusiasts.
Initially available in Japan from mid-February, it reflects a trend in motion-sensitive phones, similar to a South Korean model that simulates fishing and tracks running metrics.
